Package game.util

Class AI

java.lang.Object
game.util.AI
public class AI extends Object
The class AI holds the methods for determining what move will the computer make. This class defines the computer's artificial intelligence. The class AI's methods will help the computer place a marker if itself is about to win or if the player is about to win.

  • Method Details

    • computerTurn

      public static JButton[][] computerTurn​(int winCount, String playerIndicator, String computerIndicator, JButton[][] buttons, int yCheck, int xCheck)
      The computerTurn method is the main deciding factor in what the computer's next turn will be. If the computer is about to win in the next turn, then it will try to win. If the player is about to win in the next turn, then the computer will block it. If there isn't a computer's marker in the board yet, then it will place one in a random place. If none of these conditions apply, then it will choose a random direction and place markers next to each other until one of previously mentioned conditions apply.
      Parameters:
      winCount - The user's given input for how many markers must be next to each other to win.
      playerIndicator - The String variable containing player's marker "X".
      computerIndicator - The String variable containing computer's marker "O".
      buttons - The main 2d-array where all the buttons are stored.
      yCheck - The last position of the player's last clicked button in the y-axis.
      xCheck - The last position of the player's last clicked button in the x-axis.
      Returns:
      The 2d-array buttons modified by the AI class methods.

    • aiActionPlacement

      public static JButton[][] aiActionPlacement​(JButton[][] buttons, int winCount, String indicator, String opponentIndicator, int yCheck, int xCheck)
      The method aiActionPlacement is a method that places a marker for computer if the computer is one marker away from winning or if the player is one marker away from winning. It uses a method called aiCheckHelper to get a number which dictates the computers next move.
      Parameters:
      buttons - The main 2d-array where all the buttons are stored.
      winCount - The user's input for how many markers must be next to each other to win.
      indicator - A String variable that is counted to check for a win. Can be either computer's or player's.
      opponentIndicator - A String variable that will break the count for a win if there is one. Can be either computer's or player's.
      yCheck - The last known position of a marker on the y-axis. Can be either computer's or player's.
      xCheck - The last known position of a marker on the x-axis. Can be either computer's or player's.
      Returns:
      The 2d-array in which the computer has placed a marker.

    • aiNoActionPlacement

      public static JButton[][] aiNoActionPlacement​(JButton[][] buttons, String computerIndicator, int yCheck, int xCheck)
      The method aiNoActionPlacement kicks in when neither computer or player is about to win. It will get a random number, which will dictate the direction where the computer will start to place it's markers. If it encounters a player marker or the egde of the array, it will generate a new random direction and continue placing markers. It also contains a loopstopper for situations where the computer cannot find any direction to go to. When it has looped for about 50 times without a resolution, the computer will use the defaultPlacement method for it's next move.
      Parameters:
      buttons - The main 2d-array where all the buttons are stored.
      computerIndicator - The String variable of the marker that will be put on the button.
      yCheck - The last position of the computer's last placed marker on the y-axis.
      xCheck - The last position of the computer's last placed marker on the x-axis.
      Returns:
      The 2d-array of buttons that the computer has edited.

    • defaultPlacement

      public static JButton[][] defaultPlacement​(JButton[][] buttons, String computerIndicator)
      The defaultPlacement method is used as a failsafe and when the application starts. It will generate two random numbers and place the computer's marker in those coordinates. It is used only when the aiNoActionPlacement method cannot find a free space to put a marker and when the application first starts and there is no computer's marker yet on the board.
      Parameters:
      buttons - The main 2d-array where all the buttons are stored.
      computerIndicator - The String variable of a computer's marker.
      Returns:
      The 2d-array where computer has put it's marker.

    • aiCheckHelper

      public static int aiCheckHelper​(JButton[][] buttons, int winCount, String indicator, String opponentIndicator, int yCheck, int xCheck)
      The method aiCheckHelper is the main decider when it comes to what the computer will do next. It gets the position of the last placed marker and from there will check every direction for a possible win. If it finds it, the method will return a number corresponding a direction where the win would occur. If it doesn't find a possible win, the method instead will return a default number which tells other methods that there wasn't a possible win.
      Parameters:
      buttons - The main 2d-array where all the buttons are stored.
      winCount - The user's input for how many markers must be next to each other to win.
      indicator - The String variable that will count towards possible win.
      opponentIndicator - The String variable that will break the count when found.
      yCheck - The last position of the last placed marker (be it computer's or player's) on the y-axis.
      xCheck - The last position of the last placed marker (be it computer's or player's) on the x-axis.
      Returns:
      An integer corresponding to one of the directions that other methods will use or the default integer.

    • firstPlacement

      public static boolean firstPlacement​(JButton[][] buttons, String computerIndicator)
      The method firstPlacement is only used at the start of the application when the computer hasn't put any markers in the array. This method will look for a button with a "O" text and if it doesn't find it, it will return a true statement. If it finds one, it will return a false statement.
      Parameters:
      buttons - The main 2d-array where all the buttons are stored.
      computerIndicator - A String variable indicating the computer's marker.
      Returns:
      A true or false statment whether it finds a button with an "O" text or not.
